verses.text: My son, pay attention to my wisdom, listen well to my words of insight,

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5
rsbNotes.text: 5:1–23 This passage is best taken as a single unit. While vv. 15–23 are conceivably a distinct composition, the theme is a logical development of what goes before. Wisdom urges us to avoid the life-destroying adulteress and to find sexual and emotional satisfaction in faithfulness to the marriage bond.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5:1–6
rsbNotes.text: 5:1–6 These verses describe the character of the seducing adulteress. On the surface she is all sweetness and light, but underneath is the stench of death.

verses.text: that you may maintain discretion and your lips may preserve knowledge.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5:2
rsbNotes.text: 5:2 lips may guard knowledge. The sense may be that one should learn to maintain discreet silence when necessary, or possibly, that one should have something of substance to say (Mal. 2:7).

verses.text: For the lips of an adulteress drip honey, and her speech is smoother than oil;

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5:3
rsbNotes.text: 5:3 In contrast with v. 2, the seducer begins with deceptive words of charm. Cf. the sweetness of true love in Song 4:11.

verses.text: but in the end she is bitter as gall, sharp as a double-edged sword.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5:4
rsbNotes.text:
5:4 in the end. The phrase speaks of the end result for the victim of seduction.

bitter as wormwood. A plant especially bitter to the taste, wormwood is used as a metaphor for the experience of affliction (Deut. 29:18).

two-edged sword. The smoothness of her words is deceptive (v. 3), and the liaison leads only to injury.

verses.text: Her feet go down to death; her steps lead straight to the grave.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5:5
rsbNotes.text:
5:5 death. Not merely a matter of an early demise brought about by dissolute living, “death” in this context is all that does not promote “life” as defined by God.

Sheol. The place of the dead. Disorderly life leads to physical death. See Is. 14:9–11 note.

verses.text: She gives no thought to the way of life; her paths are crooked, but she knows it not.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5:6
rsbNotes.text: 5:6 her ways wander. The moral censure here is inseparable from the wisdom idea that folly and wickedness involve a rejection of God’s order and plan for things.
